title: Richard Bacon ‘can’t stop at one drink’ and admits he’s ‘addicted to alcohol’
text:
Richard opened up on his alcohol addiction (Picture: Rex Features)

Richard Bacon has revealed he ‘can’t stop at one drink’, leading him to believe he’s an alcoholic.

The 43-year-old TV presenter, who just over a year ago was placed into a coma for six days, admitted that excessive drinking had created ‘chaos’ in his life.

In a moment of reflection he admitted he perhaps should have sought treatment to get his drinking under control.

‘I find it very hard not to keep going … if I have one drink, I want another, and another,’ he said recently on BBC Radio 5 Live’s Hooked podcast.

‘I am jealous of people who only have one glass of wine and are content … I just want the journey to keep going.’

With wife Rebecca McFarlane (Picture: Getty Images Europe)

Richard – who was sacked from Blue Peter in 1998 after he admitted to taking cocaine – confessed to drinking excessively when he’s in a happy mood.

‘I am almost at my most vulnerable when things are great … I don’t use [drink] to numb pain,’ he continued.

‘If I am excited or happy about something, I am more likely to go too far.’

Richard also candidly explained how alcohol had driven him to use cocaine.

He said: ‘When I’ve been through periods of my life where I have been using cocaine, it’s only [after] two or three drinks where I quite fancy that as well.’

The presenter revealed he was told to got to a rehabilitation clinic, but he ‘didn’t feel like he needed to’.

Richard was placed in a coma last year (Picture: TWITTER)

The veteran presenter – who currently lives in Los Angeles with his family – has been to a number of different Alcoholics Anonymous meetings over the years.

Richard admires the work done by the organisation, but added of his own experience: ‘I never find that I really want to go.’

He added of his wife Rebecca: ‘She would like me to do AA all the time, and I just don’t, but I have said I will spend more time with our therapist examining my relationship to drink.

‘We’re in a good place at the moment, but once you have accepted you’re an addict to some degree, the danger is always there, isn’t it?’

Last July, the broadcaster was placed in a coma for six days as he battled pneumonia in both lungs. Recently his physician Dr Mick Jennings recalled that Richard would have died if action hadn’t been taken.

Richard thanked Mick, fellow Good Morning Britain guest Connie Simpson and the NHS for their lifesaving treatment, adding: ‘It’s really wonderful and moving for me to see you today. I know it seems like such a futile statement, but I’m going to say it anyway, thank you for saving my life.’
